newsitem.title: USA: Fla. judge won't change ruling in tobacco case.
newsitem.headline: Fla. judge won't change ruling in tobacco case.

text.p: A county judge has refused to change his recent ruling that sharply limits the use tobacco companies can make of Florida's history of cigarette-making in state prisons.
Palm Beach County Circuit Judge Harold Cohen issued an order late Thursday that reiterated his ruling on Feb. 3 in the landmark case scheduled for trial this summer.

In last week's ruling, the judge said that cigarette companies could not use a so-called "affirmative defense," in which a defendant tries to avoid liability by showing that a plaintiff shares responsibility for harm.

Cigarette manufacturer Philip Morris Cos Inc had asked the court to reconsider the ruling that dismissed a motion brought by tobacco groups that evidence Florida had made and sold cigarettes in its prisons should be allowed in the trial.
The judge has ruled on a series of pre-trial motions in Florida's pioneering lawsuit seeking $1 billion or more in damages for treating state residents with smoking sicknesses.
